abstract: Barbara Shaum, first woman ever allowed into McSorley's Old Ale House in East Village, reminisces about her relationship to establishment; Shaum, who is 85, ran leather goods store next to bar and was first female patron to walk through doors during business hours after city ordination banning discrimination against women was passed in 1970.
lead_paragraph: McSorley’s Old Ale House, which opened in 1854, admitted Ms. Shaum as its first female patron, in 1970, after New York City barred discrimination against women in public places.
snippet: McSorley’s Old Ale House, which opened in 1854, admitted Ms. Shaum as its first female patron, in 1970, after New York City barred discrimination against women in public places.

headline.main: The First Woman Let Into McSorley’s Reminisces (Over an Ale, of Course)
headline.print_headline: The First Woman Let Into McSorley’s Reminisces (Over an Ale, of Course)
